Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Martin Bouda
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  NA
Instructor: Martin Bouda  solid TA with complete understanding of the course, supplied personal references and documents as additional material.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda

Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin made himself available to answer questions and review material. His grading was fair and clear. My only (and limited) critical feedback is that sometimes Martin's explanations of material were more complex or confusing than Prof. Saiers. Ultimately, however, Martin was consistently able to help illuminate the material.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin was very helpful in answering questions during office hours about the material presented.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin Bouda

Instructor: Martin Bouda  [there's no prompt/question for this space - so I'll comment on my answer regarding the TA.]Question 6: 2 because neither Jim nor Martin had enough office hours, and notification of hours/review sessions should be made more than one day in advance (which happened once or twice).

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Jim is strict by fair. He created a good learning environment.

Question 7. I feel like the course could be strengthened by having field trips included, and perhaps having more project assignments with data collected in the field rather than theoretical applications and multiple midterms.Question 1 and 2. I would like to see more of the primary literature play a role in how the class is taught rather than the text book, which is designed for upper-division undergraduates. Perhaps offering a more advanced course in hydrology, and having more applications to systems students are interested in: wetland hydrology, tidal ecosystem, stream restoration, etc. I understand that the basics needs to get covered and the modeling in MatLab helped go beyond that, but I feel the applications could be more advanced and varied.
The instructor was excellent and clearly presented the material, as well as was always available to answer questions.

The course did a good job of introducing us to the fundamentals of hydrology. Overall, I am most satisfied with the teaching quality of the professor and TA, and least with the structure of the assignments and exams. The course may however be most useful to undergraduates and there really ought to be a course for graduate students with knowledge of calculus.

This class was quite challenging but really good. I think it would be helpful for the TA for this class to give a few sessions on differential equations, because they were part of the class but never thoroughly explained, and some of us have different math backgrounds.
Homeworks and exams often covered different concepts and materials. Resources folder of Classes V2 was disorganized.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I found this course really empowering, since I've largely shied away from quantitative courses at FES. Here I had the opportunity to prove to myself that I could handle a little bit of math.

Professor was responsive to making sure students learned the material. Having exams peppered throughout the semester made me study more and really learn the material (though I'm concerned about ability to retain the information in the long term given that it is fairly technical/theoretical). This course was clear and progressed in a cumulative way that made it easier to learn the material.
The video before the final exam. . .
Prof Saiers made the complex equations very clear; he made a potentially daunting subject accessible to non-experts and non-engineers.
Prof. Saires does a great job lecturing when he is in front of the class and using the white board. The pace is good and the energy and excitement is there.
Part I on groundwater, the textbook
I enjoyed the homework assignments, as they always clarified the course material. The lectures were engaging and the instructor was excellent with presenting the material.
Engaging professor and helpful TA.
The homeworks forced me to wrestle with the material

In-class group problems - way less pressure and learn from colleagues without points (and egos) riding on it.learned to use Matlab (though a tutorial with the TA on using it, for those who hadn't, would have saved me many hours...)

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: n/a

Sometimes we lose sight of the big picture. I will not remember the math equations after I graduate. I would like more 'big picture' concepts included in the course that I will be more likely to retain in the long term.
Sometimes the material was breezed through really quickly without context.
More balance between the topics: we seemed to cram a great deal of complex material into the final weeks after having spent a long time covering simpler topics in the beginning of the semester.

I wish we had more homework assignments or more practice problems in general. I think the Matlab questions on the homework were somewhat of a waste of time. I think it would have been better if we did more calculations similar to those on the test.
More field trips and more advanced applications.

Provide more practice problems that are similar to those on the test - even if they're just for practice. Homework 1 was good, in that related clearly to all of the other materials. The homework assignments felt more disjointed as the course went on (though not entire disjointed, but they weren't always great practice for the exam).Furthermore, assess students' abilities at the start of the course and be more supportive of the varying levels of ability. The group in-class project near the beginning of the course was not only good practice, but it provided greater interaction among students that, if further pursued, could have led to valuable partnerships to better understand the material.
I thought the course was great, and cannot think of any improvements. It was well-organized and run very smoothly.
The homework assignments felt disconnected from the lecture, in that some of the methods required for the homework required a series of assumptions that did not come naturally from the lectures.
Take some time to explain differential equations and integration.
Mat Lab modelling exercises most valuable after reviewed in class, not during assignment

Find out why students are taking the course, and provide interesting research articles about those topics within hydrology, perhaps like Mark Bradford's soil science class, a discussion section could be part of the class where competing ideas in environmental hydrology could be discussed once students master the necessary content...?
Organize and post lecture slides.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a
NA
An optional lab section/ field trip section would be amazing.
See above for ideas for incorporating some lab/discussion/field component

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Martin was incredibly helpful and accessible.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin was a good TA in that he was willing to meet students and explain concepts to them. He could have made more study sessions available for students.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin was incredibly helpful, holding extra sessions for studying and reviewing the homework.

Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin's explanations, though likely correct, sometimes did not line up with the way in which Jim taught the concepts in class. While I appreciated Martin's desire to more fully explain the nuances of various issues, it sometimes ended up simply confusing the issue more than clarifying it.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Very helpful, supportive, and available
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Martin was very helpful in clarifying material during office hours and in review sessions, and he was always available to answer questions.
Instructor: Martin Bouda  Clear explanations, very responsive and friendly.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm interested in watershed management, so this course was a critical complement to my forestry studies.
One of the best classes at Yale for water resources.
geology major, interested in water-rock interaction.

My first course in hydrology, I am interested in wetland and riparian ecology, ecological restoration, climate change mitigation policy and science. An understanding of hydrology is essential for these interests.
This course was integral to my studies in water resource management, and I will use the material I learned often in my future career.
Fundamental to my research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: see above.

Needed another physical sciences credit for my MF degree; Professor has good reputation as aninstructor; understanding the basics of hydrology seems important for anyone pursuing a career in natural resource management.
To learn about hydrology.
see above.

I'm interested in water management and infrastructure. I think it is important to understand all the different ways that professionals approach and speak about water issues. This class has introduced me to the technical vocabulary of flow and measurement.
Required

I took away several concepts related to groundwater and surface water hydrology that will further enhance my understanding of water flow through a variety of systems, so I am thankful for learning them in this course.
To understand hydrology in order to work on water resources issues.
needed it as a foundation for research
Because my concentration is in water quality and hydrology, and this course was essential.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes, though I'm concerned that I will not retain much of the material (if you don't use it regularly, it's hard to retain).
Definitely and then some.
yes. solid reinforcement of beginning principals, with some application.
Yes.

The course was much more theoretical than I expected, and we spent more time deriving equations than I had imagined we would. I think it is useful to understand the concepts, but I'd like to see more application.
Yes, indeed.
Would haveliked more of a focus on the peer reviewed literature.
yes

Not entirely - Much of what we did was in computer models, though models (construction, parameterization, precision/accuracy) were not the stated focus of the course. My impressions having taken the course are that hydrology is synonymous with modeling, and that I cannot use hydrological principles/information without having a model already built that I can use on the given scenario

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA
discussion, strategy.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: keep up with the readings, take lots of notes, and set aside a few hours for homework.
Course is not as intimidating as you may think -- the math concepts are relatively simple and you ease into it. Several exams and problem sets throughout the semester, but they are not too strenuous.
Give the homework lots of time.
Take the course
I would advise reviewing the material presented in class often and doing the practice problems in the textbook to help enforce the subject matter.
Good mathematical intro.

Review a bit of calculus and differential equations and integration before the course- while we never had to do differential equation perse, all of what we learned was based on this, and lacking that fundamenta understanding prevented me from understanding where the equations we used actually came from because I could not follow the process.
